description: High entropy detected in DNS domain queries for 'youtu.be', which is unusual and could indicate covert channel or tunneling attempts using DNS requests.
Forwarded DNS queries with high entropy domain 'youtu.be' suggests possible DNS tunneling or exfiltration attempts using DNS forwarding.
Query for high entropy domain 'youtu.be' from an internal IP address indicating possible suspicious DNS query generation internally.
Forwarded query for suspicious high entropy domain 'youtu.be' to another internal IP, indicating lateral movement or internal DNS abuse.
DNS reply for 'youtu.be' with associated IP address after anomalous high entropy query, potentially completing the suspicious DNS request cycle.
Additional DNS reply for 'youtu.be' confirming repeated high entropy DNS responses, consistent with abnormal DNS activity.
Unusually low frequency of DNS A-record queries for 'mail.price.fox.org' compared to expected, indicating possible reconnaissance or evasion behavior.
New event type detected involving IMAP login disconnection with no authentication attempts, possibly indicating automated login attempts or scanning activity.
Repeated detection of new IMAP login disconnect event with no auth attempts, reinforcing suspicion of brute force or scanning attempts on mail server.
Additional record of new IMAP login disconnect event without auth attempts, indicating persistent unusual login behavior.
Log indicates 'no host name found for IP address 192.168.130.77', which could imply suspicious scanning or reconnaissance activities where reverse DNS lookup fails.
Repeated log entry with no hostname for IP 192.168.130.77; consistent with scanning or probing attempts without proper DNS resolution.
Apache error log shows client denied by server configuration for IP 192.168.130.77 accessing /var/www/html/, indicating possible unauthorized access attempts or reconnaissance.
Another client denied error, this time for IP 172.17.130.196, indicating repeated unauthorized access attempts blocked by server.
No host name found for IP 192.168.130.77 again; strengthens indication of scanning or reconnaissance behavior.
TLS handshake error on connection from IP 192.168.130.77 indicates abnormal TLS traffic, possibly due to malformed packets or attempts to exploit TLS vulnerabilities.
Yet another 'no host name found' event for IP 192.168.130.77; consistent with previous reconnaissance activity.
Apache access log shows HTTP 403 Forbidden response to GET request with User-Agent referencing Nmap Scripting Engine, indicating active scanning or service enumeration.
HTTP 403 response to POST request to /sdk with Nmap User-Agent suggests a scanning tool probing for services or vulnerabilities.
HTTP 403 response to GET request on root path, also with no User-Agent, aligns with automated scanning activity to enumerate accessible services.
HTTP 403 response to POST request from Nmap Scripting Engine user-agent; indicates scanning or probing restricted endpoints
HTTP 403 response to POST request from Nmap Scripting Engine user-agent; probing blocked resource
Apache error log showing 'client denied by server configuration' accessing /HNAP1; typical of attempts to access unauthorized management interfaces
Repeated denial of access to /HNAP1 resource; indicates automated attempts to find vulnerable interfaces
Client denied accessing /HNAP1 directory; likely reconnaissance or exploitation attempts
Access denied to root web directory (/var/www/html); may indicate brute force or probing activity
Access denied to root web directory (/var/www/html) by client; scanning for vulnerabilities or misconfigurations
403 Forbidden response on GET to /wp-content/plugins/akismet/, user-agent WPScan scanner; scanning WordPress plugins for vulnerabilities
404 response on HEAD request to /wp-content/plugins/analytics-for-wp/, user-agent WPScan; scanning for WordPress plugin existence
404 response on HEAD request to /wp-content/plugins/animate-it/, user-agent WPScan; plugin enumeration attempt
HEAD requests to various WordPress plugin directories returning 404 suggest automated scanning for vulnerable plugins by WPScan tool.
HEAD request targeting 'analytify-analytics-dashboard-widget' plugin directory with 404 response indicates scanning activity.
HEAD request for 'post-snippets' plugin directory returning 404; typical of scanning for vulnerable WordPress plugins.
HEAD request for 'post-types-order' plugin directory, 404 response; part of automated plugin vulnerability enumeration.
HEAD request to 'post-type-switcher' plugin directory detected; WPScan fingerprinting for potential exploits.
HEAD request aimed at 'postmark-approved-wordpress-plugin' plugin directory with 404, indicating scanning behavior.
HEAD request targeting 'postie' WordPress plugin directory, 404 status implies probe for vulnerable plugins.
HEAD request for 'timthumb.php' in WordPress theme directory returning 404; timthumb is known vulnerable file often targeted.
HEAD request to malformed path with double slash in theme directory targeting timthumb.php; indicates probing for known vulnerable scripts.
HEAD request to a corrupted filename 'timthumb.phptimthumb.php' suggesting automated scanning for vulnerable scripts in themes.
Detected HEAD requests targeting WordPress theme files with the WPScan user agent, indicating automated scanning for vulnerabilities.
Detected HEAD requests targeting WordPress theme PHP files with WPScan user agent, showing automated probing.
GET requests to .htpasswd file which is a common attempt to access credential files, resulting in 403 Forbidden status.
GET request to a slightly altered .htpasswd_ file likely probing for misconfigurations or backup files, blocked with 403.
Request URI contains new characters '@', indicating possible command injection or probing for directory traversal.
Request URI with '~' character suggests probing for admin directories or hidden files, common in attacks against web apps.
Apache error log shows failed attempts to access WordPress sitemap PHP scripts, indicating possible file inclusion or LFI attempts.
Request contains '+' character in URI, potentially used to bypass filters or directory traversal in WordPress sitemaps.
Error log indicates attempted access to 'phpinfo.php' in WordPress sitemaps, a known target for reconnaissance or exploitation.
Request URI with '~' character in WordPress thickbox JS path, indicating attempts to access hidden or administrative resources.
Detected unusual character (~) in Apache access request targeting /wp-includes/js/thickbox/~www, possibly probing for hidden or sensitive files.
Apache error log shows denial of directory listing for /wp-includes/js/thickbox/, indicating probe attempts on directory contents.
Client denied by server configuration when trying to access /wp-includes/js/thickbox/.hta file, indicating probing for .hta files which can affect server behavior.
New HTTP 301 redirect status code for request to /wp-includes/js/tinymce/langs, indicating potential attempts to bypass or map server redirects.
New special character (+) detected in request path /wp-includes/js/tinymce/lost+found, possibly probing for unusual paths or directories.
HTTP 301 status code detected for access to /wp-includes/js/tinymce/plugins, indicating attempts to follow redirects or discover new plugin paths.
Error log reports missing phpinfo.php script in /wp-includes/js/tinymce/, which attackers commonly request to gather PHP configuration details.
New 301 redirect status code for /wp-includes/js/tinymce/skins, likely an attempt to enumerate accessible skin files or directories.
HTTP 301 redirect observed for /wp-includes/js/tinymce/themes, indicating further enumeration of theme directories via redirects.
Error log indicates missing file /wp-content/themes/go/includes/classes/index.php, a common probe for WordPress theme vulnerabilities.
Request contains unusual '+' character in path '/wp-content/themes/go/includes/classes/lost+found', indicating probing for hidden or backup files.
404 error for PHP file 'info.php' in theme directory indicates attacker scanning for potentially sensitive or exploitable scripts.
404 error for 'phpinfo.php', a common reconnaissance target, suggests attacker probing for PHP configuration exposure.
HTTP 403 Forbidden status code on access to '/wp-includes/js/tinymce/plugins/hr/' suggests attacker attempting to access restricted plugin resources.
Requests with unusual '~' character in paths (e.g. '/wp-content/themes/go/dist/images/admin/~logs') likely indicate attacker probing for backup or hidden files.
Repeated requests with '~' in paths such as '/wp-content/themes/go/dist/images/admin/~lp' indicate continued probing for hidden resources.
Similar requests to '/wp-content/themes/go/dist/images/admin/~mail' with '~' character suggest enumeration of hidden or backup files.
Requests for '/wp-content/themes/go/dist/images/admin/~nobody' indicate probing for misconfigured or hidden files.
Requests including '~operator' in the path suggest attacker looking for hidden user or operator files.
404 error for '/wp-content/themes/go/dist/images/admin/info.php' confirms repeated attempts to locate potentially exploitable PHP scripts.
Request for a suspicious wp-content path containing 'lost+found', which is uncommon and indicates probing for hidden or admin content.
Error log shows a request for 'phpinfo.php' which is a common reconnaissance step to gather server configuration details.
Access denied (403) on wp-content themes path, indicating attempt to access restricted resource or directory.
403 status for '.hta' file in themes directory, likely probing for execution of malicious scripts.
403 on attempt to access '.htpasswd' file, typical attempt to access authentication credentials.
403 for '.htpasswd_' file, variant of credential file probing.
Request path contains '@' character, which is unusual and may indicate probing or injection attempts.
Request path contains '~' character indicating possible attempt to access backup or admin directories.
Request for path containing '~admin' which is a known pattern for admin directories, indicating targeted probing.
Client denied by server configuration for '.htaccess' file, indicating probing for access control files.
Client denied by server configuration accessing sensitive .htaccess_ file, indicating possible reconnaissance or probing.
Client denied by server configuration accessing .htpasswd file, a common target for attackers trying to gain password hashes.
Client denied by server configuration accessing a disguised .htpasswd_ file, suggesting repeated probing of access controls.
Script file admin.php not found or inaccessible, indicating probing for vulnerable admin scripts.
Script file index.php in admin directory missing or inaccessible, another sign of probing for admin entry points.
High entropy URL with suspicious PHP filename and encoded parameters, typical of web shell or malware payload delivery.
Encoded request parameter referencing GitHub URLs, likely attempts to download or execute malicious scripts via web shell.
Request with encoded parameters suggesting execution of shell scripts and commands remotely via web shell.
Unusual frequency of POST method on ajax.php service, potentially indicating automated or malicious API calls.
CPU utilization anomaly with significant deviation from baseline, possibly caused by malicious or faulty processes.
Unusual high-frequency DNS queries from multiple IPs indicate potential DNS reconnaissance or tunneling activity.
Anomalous frequency in Apache HTTP request methods suggests unusual or automated scanning activity.
High entropy value in Apache request indicating obfuscated or encoded payload in a PHP file, typical of web shells or remote code execution attempts.
New su command event detected for user 'phopkins' by www-data user, indicating potential privilege escalation attempt.
New path detection for su session including terminal info, consistent with suspicious user privilege escalation behavior.
Session opened for user 'phopkins' by uid=33 (www-data), confirming suspicious privilege escalation activity.
New combination of user authentication audit logs for 'phopkins' via /bin/su detected, indicating credential access.
New user accounting audit log for 'phopkins' using /bin/su, further confirming suspicious account activity.
New credential acquisition audit log detected for 'phopkins' via /bin/su, indicating possible credential theft or misuse.
New user session start audit log for 'phopkins' through /bin/su, indicating successful privilege escalation and session initiation.
